en.value: We have already looked at how to form questions in various different ways.
I go running in the morning.
What do you usually do after work?
Well, I love [k]playing[/k] football but I'm not very good. Actually, I'm looking for someone to [k]play[/k] with, do you...
Select the sports you can use with "to play".
What - to ask about a thing / specific information
You are living in France. Are you living in France?
Select the question that matches the answer you hear.
We use the verb "to go" for sports that are verbs ending in "-ing".
Select the words in the correct order.
There are three different verbs we can use when talking about sports. We use the verb "to play" for ball sports or competitive games.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Why do you get up early?
Who - to ask about a person / people
My son does karate at school.
Cool! Do you [k]play[/k] any other sports?
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Finally, we can use the verb "to do" with all other recreational activities or non-team sports.
Every Tuesday I go [k]swimming[/k] near the office. Sometimes, I also go running with a friend and then we usually eat out.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Do you want to go swimming tomorrow?
We use "to go" with "-ing" verbs when talking about sports.
Read and listen to the sentence.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Select the question that matches the answer you hear.

You've already learned a few questions such as "What time is it?" and "Where do you live?". We're now going to have a closer look at 5 words that can help you ask... hundreds of them! They are very easy to remember as they all start with "wh-"!
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Fill in the gap using the image.
Do you want to go [k]swimming[/k] tomorrow?
We can simply add one of the "wh-" words we've just seen to the beginning of a question to ask about something more specific.
How often do you play tennis?
Write the question for the following answer: "You are doing karate."
Talking about sports with "to play, to do, to go" - "Wh-" questions "what, where, when" etc.
Me? Oh no, sorry! I [k]don't[/k] do any [k]sports[/k]!
